abstract.p: Prime Min Mikhail Kasaynov tells cabinet Russia's next federal budget should be balanced for first time in government's 10-year history, even allowing for sizable increase in social spending (S)

block.p: Russia's next federal budget should be balanced for the first time in the government's 10-year history, even allowing for a sizable increase in social spending, Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov told the cabinet today.

Mr. Kasyanov, until last month Russia's finance minister, said federal spending in the proposed 2001 budget totals about $38 billion, or roughly 17 percent of Russia's gross domestic product. Inflation was estimated to run about 11 percent a year, slightly below the 12 to 14 percent projected for 2000.

Russia's next federal budget should be balanced for the first time in the government's 10-year history, even allowing for a sizable increase in social spending, Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov told the cabinet today.

Mr. Kasyanov, until last month Russia's finance minister, said federal spending in the proposed 2001 budget totals about $38 billion, or roughly 17 percent of Russia's gross domestic product. Inflation was estimated to run about 11 percent a year, slightly below the 12 to 14 percent projected for 2000.
''For the first time, we are examining basic parameters of a draft budget which has no deficit,'' he told the cabinet.

Russia's current budget runs a primary surplus, meaning that domestic programs are fully financed, but after foreign debt payments the deficit is expected to total about 1.1 percent of the gross domestic product.

The 2001 fiscal program is buoyed in part by better-than-expected performance of the nation's economy and by the government's tenatative decision to stop paying for many programs that benefit upper classes as well as the poor.
